newsitem.title: INDIA: Multinational shrs help India stocks close mixed.
newsitem.headline: Multinational shrs help India stocks close mixed.

text.p: Indian shares finished mixed on Tuesday helped by foreign fund buying in multinational stocks but big-cap local blue-chips fell, traders said.
"It was a mixed trend," said Sanjeev Choithani, chief dealer at Bombay brokerage Pashupati Advani. "The market was down for most of the day on position unwinding."
Dealers said arbitrage trades based on price differentials at the Bombay and National exchanges helped push prices higher at close on the Bombay bourse.
The benchmark Bombay share index closed 14.94 points, or 0.35 percent, higher at 4,306.39, after hitting 4,252.49.
Some of the multinational shares that rose were: Castrol, Cadbury's, Colgate, Nestle, P&G, Pfizer, Parke Davis, German Remedies, SmithKline Beecham Pharmaceuticals and Reckitt & Colman.
"Only the FIIs (foreign institutional investors) are buying," said Shailesh Merchant, a Bombay broker.
Traders said curbs on fresh FII purchases in HDFC and Infosys imposed by the central bank on Monday triggered a speculative sell-off.
The Reserve Bank of India said foreign portfolio holdings in the two firms had reached a 26 percent watch-list limit and fresh purchases would need the bank's prior approval.
The ceiling on FII stakes in the two firms is 30 percent.
HDFC fell 221 rupees to 4,311 and Infosys lost 49.75 to 2,120, both provisional closings.
Traders said they expect the market to show a steadier trend on Wednesday.
"Tomorrow we could see a steadier trend," said Vijay Pandya, chief dealer at Classic Share and Stock Brokers.
